poem:
### Winter Rail Reverie

In the stillness of Europe,  
tracks snake through frost,  
windows breathing fog.  

Emptiness hums softly  
with the promise of chance—  
landscapes painted  
in quiet hues.  

The train a brush,  
etching journeys  
on the cold canvas  
of January's sigh.  

Here, spontaneity smiles,  
cradled in the arms of winter.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Winter rail adventures in Europe: three itineraries for the colder months I travel through Europe by rail in all seasons and all weathers, and my more memorable journeys are often in that slack period between Epiphany (on 6 January) and Easter. Fewer travellers are on the move. Empty trains and plentiful accommodation make a winning combo for those who relish spontaneous travel. And winter weather often lends a special hue to landscape, be it creeping". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.

And winter weather often lends a special hue to landscape, be it creeping
